docs.lead_paragraph: Laparoscopic hernia surgery may be less painful than a traditional open incision, but it carries a higher risk of recurrence, except when highly experienced surgeons perform it, said a study released on Sunday. The study, presented at a conference of the American College of Surgeons in Boston, will be published Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: A Basic Option in Hernia Repair

docs.abstract: Dr Leigh Neumayer, Salt Lake City Veterans Affairs Medical Center researcher, leads study on laparoscopic hernia surgery that shows procedure is less painful for patient, but carries higher risk of recurrent problems than open incision surgery; study was presented at American College of Surgeons conference in Boston and in New England Journal of Medicine (S)
docs.snippet: Laparoscopic hernia surgery may be less painful than a traditional open incision, but it carries a higher risk of recurrence, except when highly experienced surgeons perform it, said a study released on Sunday.     The study, presented at a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Although it may seem that the standard of beauty promoted by cosmetic surgery is uniform, surgeons say that there are regional and national variations and that the ideals have changed over time. Neither noses nor breasts, the bread and butter of cosmetic surgery, are what they used to be. At the annual meeting of the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery here last week, the president of the society, Dr. Robert W. Bernard, said in an interview that when he started out ''the look among youngsters was a little, tiny turned-up nose.'' Now he said, it is more natural.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert W Bernard, American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery president, holds that popularity of various procedures is different for patients in different regions (S)
docs.snippet: Although it may seem that the standard of beauty promoted by cosmetic surgery is uniform, surgeons say that there are regional and national variations and that the ideals have changed over time.    Neither noses nor breasts, the bread and butter of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Remedial programs for students with dyslexia often succeed only in making bad readers into slightly better bad readers. Now a new study shows that more aggressive treatment can make dyslexic brains work the way normal brains do, activating a region that plays a vital role in reading fluency. Good and bad readers handle tasks differently, brain scanning research has shown, from the processing of sound to the recall of vocabulary. Last year, a study showed that dyslexic students who were tutored with typical methods made limited gains but continued to use cumbersome mental pathways.

headline.main: A Clearer Path to Reading Fluency

docs.abstract: Dr Sally E Shaywitz, Yale University researcher, leads study on intensive treatment of dyslexia compared with standard treatment; finds that intensive work stimulates area of brain known as word-form region; study, appearing in journal Biological Psychiatry, shows considerable improvements in reading for those dyslexia students receiving intensive treatment; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Remedial programs for students with dyslexia often succeed only in making bad readers into slightly better bad readers. Now a new study shows that more aggressive treatment can make dyslexic brains work the way normal brains do, activating a region...

docs.lead_paragraph: Any medical procedure poses some risks, and that includes surgery performed simply to look good. By definition, in elective surgery any risk is unnecessary. But people take a variety of unnecessary risks -- riding horses, scuba diving -- for a variety of reasons. Depending on the point of view, jowls or bags under the eyes may be a very good reason. First, doctors say, patients should be aware that the risks are there. At a meeting of the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery here last week, surgeons in presentations and interviews said patients should realize that even common procedures like liposuction can be hazardous. People have died having it.

headline.main: Learning the Risks of Looking Good

docs.abstract: American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery suggests that patients considering cosmetic surgery should check doctor specialties and credentials and thoroughly understand risks of procedure before having surgery (S)
docs.snippet: Any medical procedure poses some risks, and that includes surgery performed simply to look good. By definition, in elective surgery any risk is unnecessary. But people take a variety of unnecessary risks -- riding horses, scuba diving -- for a...

docs.lead_paragraph: When doctors complain they have no time, they don't just mean what everybody means: no time to do their work, their paperwork, their homework, and still see the kids. At work, doctors now face a worsening shortage of time: that's time as in tincture of, one of the best drugs and diagnostic tools around. Time soothes pain, cures fevers, knits broken bones, and it can outperform the most expensive scanner on the planet. Combine a little time with some food, a bed and a set of good nurses, and wonderful medical care can result.

headline.main: Time Heals, but It's a Luxury Physicians and Patients Rarely Get

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger Cases column gives two medical examples in which patients would have benefited from more days in hospital; holds that hospitals often try to discharge patients too early in order to save money (M)
docs.snippet: When doctors complain they have no time, they don't just mean what everybody means: no time to do their work, their paperwork, their homework, and still see the kids.    At work, doctors now face a worsening shortage of time: that's time as in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Most women experience morning sickness early in their pregnancies. But it does not necessarily strike only in the morning, nor does it always end after the first trimester. I, for one, felt sick at various times of the day, especially when I smelled something off-putting, like garbage or meat being cooked, and every day on the subway on my way home, until I realized that it helped to eat something before I left the office.

headline.main: Reasons, and Remedies, for Morning Sickness

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses morning sickness during pregnancy which affects 70 to 80 percent of pregnant women; new report by American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists issues guidelines for 2 percent of pregnancies that involve severe symptoms called hyperemesis gravidarum; possible reasons for nausea and vomiting discussed; taking multivitamins, eating smaller meals and avoiding certain foods are suggested for pregnant women experiencing such symptoms; hospitalization for hyperemesis gravidarum discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Most women experience morning sickness early in their pregnancies. But it does not necessarily strike only in the morning, nor does it always end after the first trimester.    I, for one, felt sick at various times of the day, especially when I...

docs.lead_paragraph: Several times a day, Dr. Tom Delbanco sits in front of his computer, opens his e-mail and fields questions from his patients. Electronic communications between doctors and patients, he says, may be the next best thing to a home visit.

headline.main: Take Two Aspirin, E-Mail Me Tomorrow

docs.abstract: Quarter of practicing doctors communicate with patients through email; Dr Tom Delbanco, Harvard University Medical School professor and lead author of article in New England Journal of Medicine on doctors and email, finds that patients are often more comfortable with talking through email than directly with doctor; doctors also see advantages to email; practical advice about emailing physician given (M)
docs.snippet: Several times a day, Dr. Tom Delbanco sits in front of his computer, opens his e-mail and fields questions from his patients.    Electronic communications between doctors and patients, he says, may be the next best thing to a home visit.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the average backseat driver, about the only thing worse than taking the wrong exit on a busy highway is watching someone else take the wrong exit -- from the passenger seat. So it may not be surprising that the brain of a scolding passenger shows the same pattern of activity as that of an irritated driver.

headline.main: Passengers Feel the Driver's Anxiety, Too

docs.abstract: Dr Michael G H Coles, research fellow at Donders Center for Cognitive Neuroimaging, Netherlands, leads study appearing in journal Nature Neuroscience that shows that bystanders of errors register same anxiety in brain scans as person performing error (M)
docs.snippet: For the average backseat driver, about the only thing worse than taking the wrong exit on a busy highway is watching someone else take the wrong exit -- from the passenger seat.    So it may not be surprising that the brain of a scolding passenger...

docs.lead_paragraph: It's not the heat, it's the humidity that appears to be to blame in some cases when laser surgery to correct nearsightedness, known as Lasik, falls short, a new study has concluded. The study was conducted by Dr. Keith A. Walter, an assistant professor of ophthalmology at Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C.

headline.main: A Steam Factor in Laser Surgery

docs.abstract: Dr Keith A Walter, Wake Forest University assistant ophthalmology professor, studies data on 191 patients and finds link between humidity in treatment room and success of Lasik, eye laser correction surgery; undercorrections were found to be most common after period of high humidity; findings are published in Journal of Cataract and Refractive Surgery; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: It's not the heat, it's the humidity that appears to be to blame in some cases when laser surgery to correct nearsightedness, known as Lasik, falls short, a new study has concluded.    The study was conducted by Dr. Keith A. Walter, an assistant...

docs.lead_paragraph: When a whole doctor's office gets involved in helping smokers quit, the success rate more than doubles, a study in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute has reported. The study followed more than 2,000 smokers who were treated by eight medical clinics in Wisconsin. Workers in four of the clinics were trained using the methods recommended by federal guidelines, which are rarely followed, the study noted. The other four clinics served as a control group.
docs.abstract: Dr David A Katz, University of Wisconsin researcher, leads study on doctor's office-based plan to help people quit smoking; study, published in Journal of the National Cancer Institute, shows that when staff at medical clinics give counseling and other support to patients who smoke that patients are three times more likely to give up cigarettes than those left on their own; drawing (S)
